ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed much more proficiency in Russian grammar and vocabulary and learned more about Russian history.

I furthered my study of the Russian language: emphasis on fluent communication in class, discussion of historical events, presenting material fluently. We also explored difficult grammatical concepts like Verb aspect and motion verbs in greater depth.
Greatly increased knowledge of Russian, especially in terms of passive comprehension (e.g., reading and listening).

Developed high level of Russian grammar and fluency. I gained insights not only on the language but on Russian culture too - conversations and practice of grammar was often grounded in learning about Russian History - which I really loved.
Improved mastery of Russian grammatical and colloquial conventions. Also learned imperial history in the Russian language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths  Professor Muravnik and the class is very organized

Overall, it was organized very well, but it felt like all the projects and exams hit during the last 2 weeks, especially when dealing with a harder grammatical topic. More opportunities for speaking would also be helpful to develop more everyday skills potentially.

Strengths: Professor Muravnik is an awesome professor. His understanding of how to teach grammar in a comprehensible way makes his lectures super valuable. Format of the class in general is conducive to student learning and improving one's fluency. Weakness: my one suggestion is to make deadlines for the individual assignments (i.e. presentations, home reading assignments, and discussions) in order to space them out, as without deadlines we all procrastinated and wound up cramming everything into the last week of school, which was very hectic. Note to future self: don't leave so many assignments to the last minute!
The class is excellent in terms of developing passive Russian proficiency; however the lesser emphasis on the speaking component means that your proficiency can feel somewhat lopsided by the end.
The strengths are the Professor - he has curated a wonderful syllabus. Weaknesses are hard to find.
Very engaging and organized professor, small class sizes improve opportunities for clarification and student engagement, but near the end of the semester too many assignments were assigned.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Take required prerequisites first though
If you want to grow Russian language skill and have an interest in Russian Imperial history absolutely!
Wholeheartedly recommend! Professor Muravnik is an excellent teacher! Totally take this course if you want to further your understanding of Russian!

Absolutely, if you're willing to put the hours in and really want to become proficient in Russian. If you have a sort of analytical learning style, the phonological and grammar explanations will be especially suited to helping you internalize a more instinctive understanding of the language.
Yes definitely - if you love languages/Russian/History - this class is so great!

If you are considering improving your fluency with the Russian language, this course is a must. It is well-organized to support student engagement and the professor works with you to ensure you are keeping up with class material.
